properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A further 10 to 20 cm of snow expected tonight and Wednesday morning. A slow moving frontal system over B.C. will exit the province on Wednesday. . Heavy snowfall associated with this storm will redevelop this evening and then taper off Wednesday morning. Reported snowfall amounts range from about 15 to 20 cm near Blue River and near 40 cm at Mica Dam. A further 10 to 20 cm of snow is expected. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-04T14:49:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-03T22:50:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1165727919.2019
Area: North Columbia, Kinbasket
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong westerly winds, with gusts at times over 100 km/h, will continue tonight and into Wednesday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lasting blizzard conditions, with visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow, are expected to develop by Wednesday evening. Although visibility may intermittently improve, hazardous conditions are forecast to persist into Friday. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-04T20:49:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-04T04:50:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0741614895.2019
Area: Tuktoyaktuk - East Channel Region

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of significant freezing rain is occurring. Locations: central and western Newfoundland. Time span: this evening until early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Freezing rain will continue tonight. Total amounts of up to 10 mm are possible for parts of central and western Newfoundland. Precipitation is expected to change to rain for all areas by early Wednesday morning. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-04T13:59:54-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix is expected. Locations: the Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: tonight to Wednesday morning. Possible snowfall: 10 to 15 cm Remarks: A mixture of freezing rain, ice pellets and snow is expected over the Great Northern Peninsula tonight and Wednesday. Maximum snowfall is expected over northern portions near the Strait. Freezing rain is possible over southern portions of the region, with ice pellets in between. Snow is expected to taper off by Wednesday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-04T13:59:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-04T02:24:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2018978229.2019
Area: Northern Peninsula East, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected tonight and Wednesday. Locations: Eagle River, Cartwright to Black Tickle, and the Strait. Time span: tonight until Wednesday evening. Possible snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Remarks: Precipitation has begun in the Straits area and will spread to the rest of southeastern and central Labrador during the night. Areas along the coast from Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair are likely to see less accumulation as the snow is expected to be wet and mix with ice pellets. However, areas inland along the Trans Labrador Highway could see up to 15 cm by Wednesday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-04T18:24:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-04T02:25:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2866343396.2019
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair, Cartwright to Black Tickle, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong westerly winds will intensify along the Mackenzie Delta on Wednesday afternoon. The winds are expected to combine with fresh snowfall to give blizzard conditions over Tuktoyaktuk starting early Wednesday evening. There are now indications that the blizzard will continue into Friday . This winter storm watch may be upgraded to a blizzard warning when the timing of the winds becomes more certain. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-04T14:21:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-03T22:22:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3046743221.2019
Area: Tuktoyaktuk - East Channel Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A slow moving frontal system over B.C. will exit the province on Wednesday. Heavy snowfall associated with this storm will continue through tonight and taper off Wednesday morning. Snowfall accumulations of up to 40 cm are expected for this event. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Atmospheric conditions could result in a deterioration in air quality. High concentrations of pollutants should develop this evening and persist until Wednesday morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-04T17:00:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2019-12-03T20:49:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2153081413.2019
Area: Ashuapmushuan Wildlife Reserve area, Normandin - Péribonka area, Alma - Desbiens area, Saint-Félicien - Roberval area, Falardeau - Mont-Valin area, Sainte-Rose-du-Nord area, Ville de Saguenay area, Rivière-Éternité - Petit-Saguenay area, Tadoussac - Baie-Sainte-Catherine area

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls expected to develop Wednesday afternoon or evening. Lake effect snow is expected through the day on Wednesday with local snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm possible by the evening. As colder air moves over Lake Huron late in the afternoon or evening, more intense snow squalls will develop. Snowfall accumulations up to 15 cm is possible by Thursday morning in the heaviest snow squalls. Gusty northwest winds will also lead to local blowing snow with these snow squalls The snow squalls will begin to weaken Thursday morning, with additional accumulations of 5 to 10 cm possible by Thursday afternoon. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-04T20:20:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-04T04:21:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2828814145.2019
